answers.answer: if you really want an epidural, but are aonly worried about the needle, then i can tell you, go ahead and get the epidural. i don't know about any one else, but that one or two seconds of the needle was nothing compared to the contractions. i think at the time, you will most likely be so focused on the pain of the contractions that the epidural will be a piece of cake. personally for me, i loved the epidural. it made the birthing process much less traumatic for me and didn't cloud my judgment as painkillers would. my only advice is to wait as long as you can to get the epidural. i got it at 7 cm and that worked great for me.good luck.

I went natural with both my kids. They were big too .... 9.6 and 9.7. My best advice is do your research and see what fits you best. If it's the needle that scares you the most .... trust me, you'll be begging for that neddle when you're in the thick of labor. Because a needle is nothing compared to the pain of labor.My personal reasons for going natural were the statistics and questionable side effects the narcotic has on the baby. Now this is a touchy subject and many I'm sure will disagree. But based on my trusted medical team, it was confirmed the meds do pass onto the baby. They are not "supposed" to be harmful, but do cause for a drousier baby. And since statics show breastfeeding (which was VERY important to me) a baby w/o having had an epidural is more successful. Again .... just my opinion ... don't everyone jump all over me. I'm sure MANY many many people have had drugs and breastfed very successfully. Plus it had been said having any kind of intervention while in the labor process increases your chance of having a C-section, which I wanted to avoid as much as I could. Labor generally is faster without meds as well and recovery easier.Again ... this is my PERSONAL opinion. I wanted to experience the labor process and have the best odds for a successful birthing experience. I do have a high tolerance for pain, and I am a very strong willed person. Without those two ingredients, I don't think I could have done it. It requires a lot of strength, endurance, will, and confidence. You have to know YOU CAN DO IT. Have faith in your goal and stick with it. I had a healthy pregnancy and a routine labor. Some people don't fit that mold and therefore it might not be in their best interest to go natural. You have to weight your condition and find out what works best for your personal situation. This is just my account.I wouldn't change a thing about it. It was very hard and I am very proud that I did it. I dont' consider those who opt for medication weak, I just know what works best for me. I tend to be a purest when it comes to labor and babies. I breastfed my DS until 10 months and I hope to go even longer with my DD who is 3 months now. I make homemade baby food and try and use all organic food. So having a natural labor is just part of what I believe in for myself.Good luck in your decision making process and the end of your pregnancy.

I had an epidural all three times with my babies.  I believe that you should KEEP an open mind about it.  The epidural will give you some relief, so that your labour can actually progress faster...I was also induced all 3 times, so they could up the pitocin when the epidural kicks in!  My first baby was 10lbs 4 ozs, and my 2nd was 10lbs 5 ozs and my 3rd was 7lbs 8 ozs.. and the smallest one was actually my MOST painful labour and delivery.  Best of luck to you!

sorry...not wanting to start anything...but in my own experience, all 3 of my babies were completely ALERT  when they were born, and ready to feed immediately,  I breastfed all 3 of them as soon as they weighed them and cleaned them, (within 1/2 hour of delivery ) so there were no adverse effects of the epidural.
Yes.... per my email:I'm sure MANY many many people have had drugs and breastfed very successfully.Good for you.

I was against the Epidural as well..TOTALLY against it..BUT once i felt those contractions...I basically could have given myself the epidural.I too am nervous when it comes to needles...i'm the biggest baby! But with this next baby, the first thing i['m going to ask for is the epidural.The needle is nothing compared to the contractions...i hope i'm not scaring you, but it's the truth.I nursed my dd for 10 months and no effects.God Bless those who go without it...honestly, I give you props!!!!

I didn't get an epidural, but I did get an ITA and the needle was pretty huge. I didn't even flench when they put it in...and I'm the biggest baby in the world! lol My dh was crying b/c he felt so bad for me having to get such a big needle in my back and I was the one comforting him! I say go for it!!

I was soooo worried about the Epidural because I had spinal taps and they sucked.However, I'll tell you what.... the Epidural was a god send!  I had a difficult labor, really difficult, and without the Epidural I was in so much pain I was screaming and trying to climb out of my bed (my hips wouldn't separate like they needed to).To be honest, go for the Epidural.

LOL..i think that's so funny...you were comforting him!They let you see the needle?With the Epidural...everything is covered..and they made my dh leave the room.Oh...one more thing...if i remember correctly.I think they gave me the ep. while i was having a contraction. So you really didn't have time to feel the pain of the needle...Also..they gave me hug a pillow to hold and the nurse holds you too                               ( i think i squeezed her hand too..lol..but i'm sure they are used to that)
DO the epidural...coming from someone who's birthed a 9lb baby w/out one, 8 1/2 lb w/one, then 10lb baby w/out one
10lb baby without an epidural? Are you nuts?

I had an epidural and plan to have another.  Interestingly enough, I could FEEL every painful contraction during the later stages of labor, but I did not feel the third degree tear I experienced.  That alone was worth the idea of a needle in my spine!

well, no one but the one l&d nurse believed me it was a big baby. talk about the "ring of fire" down there....w/out an episiotomy where they at least numb you. My ob tried stretching me and needless to say I got 2nd degree lacerations w/abrasions that didn't want to heal quickly. Ever see the exorcist movie? well I replayed the scene w/ her thrashing around screaming and swearing only w/me pushing the baby out. never peeped a word during my other 2
I really don't know what to say about that..but oh my goodness!!!!! I can't even imagine?!?!?!

lol, yeah, it's something that I don't want to remember, but I know I always will. Wasn't too bad considering my 1st DC labor was 16 hours with 3 long hours of pushing, 2nd DC was 47 1/2 hours (non stop) of labor and he just slid on out, and my last and biggest one yet was only 5 hours. So, I"ll take the pain down there with the really short labor :-) But, damn, I'll never forget how bad that hurt!! Imagine feeling yourself tear down there.....and no control over it.....glad I"m done having kids!
BTW, I like Jordan, and I didn't mean to scare you!! Just follow your instincts and make others listen to you. I wish I would've with all 3 of mine, as something happened with all 3 of them.

No one can tell you what to do. If you're hesitating it may be a sign that you are open to thinking carefully--something's making you think. Any decision based on fear is apt to be a bad decision.  Do you know any women that have had natural childbirth with whom you could talk?  Not alarmists or dramaqueens either.I had an epidural with baby1 and almost ended up with C-section (or worse) due to the way it depressed his heart and delayed the contractions. 20 hrs, 3 of them pushing since epidurals make it so hard to push, plus 18,000 labor&delivery bill. I am the biggest wimp with the lowest pain threshold on the planet (can barely brush my own hair) BUT for baby2 I had to try naturally. I couldn't put her through the risk. And guess what? It was okay, do-able, the pain ends and you have a healthy baby. With baby3, I was more nervous, don't know why, maybe cause I'm much older now. Still, I kept telling myself it was leading somewhere, it would be over and tomorrow I'd look back and have a baby in my arms. The cm's flew by, I stayed in hospital jacuzzi (almost named the baby jacuzzi), did my breathing---yes indeed it hurt--only thought I was going to die once (yes, from the pain) but had good people around me I trusted who told me no, I wasn't actually going to (my husband, my doctor). Whaddaya know? It was true. Pushing is downright fun when you're not on epidural and all uncoordinated.I'm proud of all 3 events in which I did the best I knew how. But after baby1 and the epi sideeffects, I knew that I could give baby better than that, even me.  BTW, baby1 was 20 hours, baby2 was 45 minutes, baby 3 was about 3 hours.  The Bradley method (get the book online or better yet a class!) is awesome--you can actually relax and be on top of contractions not a floundering thrashing bucket of fear the women describe above. That makes me cringe and I promise you that doesnt have to happen.  (PS My sister had a 11lb baby at home with no drugs, just a midwife.

I had epi's placed with all three, but only was medicated with the first. The latter two were on pumps that I had turned off. I simply wanted them in place just in case. I had three babies weighing in at 8lbs 5 ounces, 8 lbs 7 ounces, and the last one was 8 lbs 14 ounces and broke my tailbone. With that one I was wishing I would have had that dang thing pumping!!It is totally do-able as someone mentioned. I was induced with all three and had somewhat long labors in the beginning (26 hours start to finish with my first, only 12 hours with my second, and 29 hours with my third)No lingering effects with my first and I had epi meds administered very late in the game. He was alert and reayd to eat right from the start. Of course my own issues after delivery caused a delay in that, but he was anxiously awaiting my breast when he was handed to me.

My advice - DONT LOOK AT THE NEEDLE.  haha  For real - if you dont see it - it does not hurt at all.  They give it to you during contractions so you are more concentrated on not moving then the needle.  It took about 4 times for them to get it in and I did not feel any pain.  I did feel this weird feeling - kinda like you can feel it once it is inside but no pain and trust me I am a BIG baby I would tell you the truth.  Just dont look and sit still.  Oh and my opinion - YES get the epi.  I give women who did it without all the credit in the world - I had gone through a lot of physical pain with my pregnancy due to complications - I know I can take the pain but why the hell would I.  When you are pregnant they cant give you anything so I suffered through many medical procedures in labor whoo hoo you get the good stuff.  BTW I ended up with a c-section and I loved it.  They say that is more painful in the end.  i cannot compare but I never even took pain meds after I woke up.Good Luck,PS. I could not nurse but as for myself I have no side effect from the epi

my only advice is GET ONE!!!! I was not scared of the needle but I thought I could handle the pain.I was dead wrong. It hurt like #@$%. anyway I was in labor for 33 and I only made it to 3 cent. before adamently asking for the epi. I have a new found respect for any woman who can give birth without one. good luck. I would not worry about the needle anyway it did not hurt one bit.
